sub_topic: Solving systems of linear equations using Cramer's rule
message_1:
Consider the following system of linear equations:

x + 2y + z = 7

3x - 4y + 5z = -1

2x + y - 3z = 4

Using Cramer's rule, find the values of x, y, and z that satisfy the system of equations.
message_2:
To solve the system of linear equations using Cramer's rule, we first need to find the determinant of the coefficient matrix, which we'll call D. The coefficient matrix is:

| 1  2  1 |
| 3 -4  5 |
| 2  1 -3 |

D = 1((-4)(-3) - (5)(1)) - 2((3)(-3) - (5)(2)) + 1((3)(1) - (-4)(2))
D = 1(12 - 5) - 2(-9 - 10) + 1(3 + 8)
D = 1(7) - 2(-19) + 1(11)
D = 7 + 38 + 11
D = 56

Now, we'll find the determinants of the matrices obtained by replacing the first, second, and third columns of the coefficient matrix with the constant terms (7, -1, 4), respectively. We'll call these determinants Dx, Dy, and Dz.

For Dx, replace the first column with the constant terms:

| 7 -1  4 |
| 2  1 -3 |
| 3 -4  5 |

Dx = 7((-4)(5) - (1)(-3)) - (-1)((2)(5) - (1)(-3)) + 4((2)(-4) - (1)(3))
Dx = 7(-20 + 3) + 1(10 + 3) + 4(-8 - 3)
Dx = 7(-17) + 1(13) - 4(11)
Dx = -119 + 13 - 44
Dx = -150

For Dy, replace the second column with the constant terms:

| 1  7  1 |
| 3  2  5 |
| 2  3 -3 |

Dy = 1((2)(-3) - (5)(3)) - 7((3)(-3) - (5)(2)) + 1((3)(3) - (2)(2))
Dy = 1(-6 - 15) - 7(-9 - 10) + 1(9 - 4)
Dy = -21 + 7(1) + 5
Dy = -21 + 7 + 5
Dy = -9

For Dz, replace the third column with the constant terms:

| 1  2  7 |
| 3 -4 -1 |
| 2  1  4 |

Dz = 1((-4)(4) - (-1)(1)) - 2((3)(4) - (-1)(2)) + 7((3)(1) - (-4)(2))
Dz = 1(-16 + 1) - 2(12 + 2) + 7(3 + 8)
Dz = -15 - 2(14) + 7(11)
Dz = -15 - 28 + 77
Dz = 34

Now, we can find the values of x, y, and z using the determinants:

x = Dx / D = -150 / 56
y = Dy / D = -9 / 56
z = Dz / D = 34 / 56

To simplify the fractions:

x = -75 / 28
y = -9 / 56
z = 17 / 28

So, the solution to the system of linear equations is x = -75/28, y = -9/56, and z = 17/28.
